thread.title: Beavers sink to bottom of Pac-12
thread.title_full: Beavers sink to bottom of Pac-12

title: Beavers sink to bottom of Pac-12
text:
Activate your digital access. Beavers sink to bottom of Pac-12 OSU football coach Gary Andersen talks about the Beavers renaining upbeat after losing to Colorado on Oct. 24, 2015 Gary Horowitz , Statesman Journal 11:33 a.m. PDT October 25, 2015 Oregon State tailback Ryan Nall runs the ball in Saturday’s 17-13 loss to Colorado at Reser Stadium in Corvallis. (Photo: Scott Olmos-USA TODAY Sports) 6 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CORVALLIS – It seems fitting that first-year Oregon State coach Gary Andersen would draw an analogy to a ship when describing the current predicament of his football team. 
After all, following Saturday's 17-13 homecoming loss to Colorado at Reser Stadium there can be no doubt that OSU has sunk to the bottom of the Pac-12. 
The Beavers (2-5, 0-4) have lost 16 of their last 18 conference games dating to the 2013 campaign, with most of that nosedive on the watch of former coach Mike Riley. 
"Quite frankly, the young bucks are gonna keep on rolling so the old guys better make sure they stay on the ship cause it's gonna be a fun ship down the road," Andersen said following Saturday's game. "It's gonna be a lot of fun, but right now it's not." 
The "young bucks" Andersen was referring to includes redshirt freshman tailback Ryan Nall, who ran for 122 yards on 20 carries and one touchdown, accumulating much of his yardage after contact. Beavers will be hard pressed to win a Pac-12 game 
A 6-foot-2, 237-pound bruiser from Sandy, Nall had more rushing attempts against Colorado than in the previous six games combined. Senior Storm Barrs-Woods may be the sixth-leading rusher in school history, but Nall has likely arrived as the lead back. 
Andersen called Nall a "war daddy," and he represents the type of player Andersen is looking for on the recruiting trail as he attempts to rebuild the youngest team in the Pac-12 into a contender. 
"He's everything that a great football player stands for in my mind and he's a freshman, and that excites the hell out of me," Andersen said. 
But there's nothing exciting about losing to Colorado (4-4, 1-3), which ended its 14-game Pac-12 losing streak at OSU'sexpense. 
The Beavers squandered their best opportunity to avoid going winless in conference play for the first time since 1997. The Beavers are almost certain to be double-digit underdogs in their remaining games against Utah, UCLA, California, Washington and Oregon. 
Moving forward Andersen said OSU will utilize a two-quarterback system of true freshman Seth Collins and redshirt freshman Nick Mitchell, who played in his first college game Saturday. It's telling that Mitchell was on the field in the fourth quarter with the game on the line. Beavers report card 
Collins is a dynamic runner who leads the team in rushing with 536 yards, but he has struggled in the passing game. Mitchell has a more accurate arm, but lacks Collins' mobility and was sacked four times. 
The best quarterback on the roster might be junior Darel Garretson, but the transfer from Utah State won't be an option until next season due to NCAA transfer rules. 
Whether it's Collins or Mitchell or both, OSU can't win games by producing just one offensive touchdown. The offense amassed a respectable 401 total yards, but just 13 points. 
"Our defense played a really good game," Mitchell said. "At the end of the day it comes down to offense and our execution." 
Andersen has been in rebuilding mode before. Utah State was in worse shape than the Beavers when he took over in 2009, and in Year 4 under Andersen the Aggies went 11-2 and were nationally ranked in the final polls. 
But the prospect of a brighter future provides little consolation as the losses mount. 
"It sucks," junior linebacker Rommel Mageo said. "Losing's never good, especially (when) you let one slip away like that." 
The road doesn't get any easier for the Beavers beginning Saturday at Utah, which is coming off its first loss of the season at USC.
